Row.Text: Switch off lights in rooms that aren’t being used (6-11 pm during week and 8 am to 11pm on weekends).
Switch off lights in offices that aren’t being used. (7pm-7am during the week and 24hours at the weekend)
Change light bulbs to low energy bulbs
If you'd like any free bulbs please write the number of people in the group in the box below
Switch all electrical equipment off at the wall when not in use.
Unplug any chargers once they have finished charging.
When boiling the kettle, use only the amount of water that you need.
Defrost your fridge and freezer
Clean the condenser coils at the back of your fridge
Use a single lamp to illuminate only the area you are using, rather than lighting up the whole room or office.
Switch your computer/monitor off every night AND every time you are away for a long period of time
Use the stairs instead of the lift at home and at work
Change to: Get an energy monitor. Instead of: Consider getting an energy monitor.
Switch off office equipment at night
Ensure your fridge/freezer are operating at the correct temperatures.
Reduce the use of electric fans on hot days.
Maximise the use of natural daylight. Relocate work surfaces, desks and reading areas nearer to windows.
Allow frozen food to defrost before you cook it, rather than cooking from frozen.
Only iron the clothes that really need ironing.
Put lids on pans when boiling water
Turn your oven off ten minutes before your dinner is finished cooking.
Clean your windows to let in more natural light
Make sure the escalator is only running when the shop is open
Ensure that energy saving features of your computers are activated.
Fix a timer to a vending machine turning it off out of working hours.
When replacing office equipment, buy a combination fax/copier/printer.
Consider using reduced lighting in the store while you are working and the shop is closed
Check for damage to the door seal on your fridge / freezer
Keep fridges/freezers organised
Turn dishwashers off at the wall when not in use
Reduce the brightness on your TV. If you have a LCD TV, you can usually turn down the backlight
Choose the right size pan for the size of the food that you are cooking
Place a saucepan on the cooking ring that best equals it in size
Use a toaster instead of the grill for toasting bread
Chop vegetables/meats into smaller sizes when cooking
Avoid temptation to open oven as food cooks
Cook on several levels using a steamer on one cooker ring.
CHANGE TO: Use LED Christmas lights instead of the standard equivalent. INSTEAD OF: If choosing Christmas lights, consider LEDs
Use a power-down plug.
Open fridge/freezer door less often Instead of.: Close fridge/freezer doors as quickly as possible
Use the off switch on appliances instead of standby.
Long term action: When buying a new radio, buy an Energy Saving Recommended digital one.
Try to position your fridge freezer away from a heat source, e.g. oven or radiator.
Watch TV fewer nights per week, or less time each night - and do something active instead!
Long term action: Switch your electricity supplier to one that supplies green energy
When buying a new Fridge/Freezer buy one with an A+ or A++ rating
When buying a new freezer buy one with an A+ or A++ rating.
When buying a new dishwasher buy one with an A rating
When buying a new Fridge buy one with an A+ or A++ rating
'Long term action: Consider buying an induction hob when replacing an electric hob
Long term action: Paint your walls and ceilings a light colour next time you decorate
Long term action: Install occupancy sensors which turn lights on or off depending on whether there is someone in the room
Long term action: When buying a new TV, buy a small one
Long term action: Buy a pressure cooker
Long term action: Buy a slow cooker
Try to buy food that is grown or produced locally
Consider reducing the amount of meat that you eat by 50%
Consider reducing the amount of dairy products you eat by 25%
Cook a vegetarian meal
Cook a vegan meal
Make use of the work canteen
Include some (20%) local organic food in your weekly shop.
Avoid pre-prepared fruit and vegetables
Try to remember all the low carbon food rules when shopping.
Long term action: Investigate local food co-ops
Long term action: If hiring catering for events or meetings, consider asking for low carbon catering. E.g. seasonal fruit and vegetables that are in season and grown locally.
Long term action: Change to: Become self sufficient in Fruit and Vegetable. Instead of: Grow fruit if you have space in your garden & Start growing your own vegetables
Put on warmer clothes instead of turning up the heating
Turn the heat off in rooms that you are not using
Shut the doors between rooms
Turn heating down to minimal (or off) when away from home
Place insulation panels behind your radiators
Draw all your curtains at nightfall
If your heating is set above the comfortable room temperature of 18-21oC, turn it down.
Check that radiators are working properly
Make sure there is no furniture in front of your radiators
Switch off heating during the night - use an extra blanket or thicker duvet.
Only use air conditioning when it's really necessary.
Try to use open windows and doors to cool workspaces, rather than use air conditioning.
If you are using air conditioning, keep the windows and doors closed.
Set the air conditioning thermostat at the highest temperature with which you are comfortable.
Change to: Change your air conditioning filters every month Instead of: Clean your air conditioning filters
Switch the heating off 1 hour before bedtime
Experiment with altering heating and cooling thermostats. As a guide, try setting no higher than 19OC for heating and no lower than 24oC for cooling.
Long term action: Put draught proofing around doors and windows
Find out if you have the recommended 270mm depth of loft insulation. If not, consider fitting it.
Put cavity insulation in your walls
Insulate your hot water tank and pipes.
Find out if your boiler needs replacing and if there are grants available to help you.
Long term action: Install radiator thermometers
Automatic doors - make sure they only open when they are meant to.
If you are a tenant, ask for a boiler maintenance certificate from your landlord or estate agent.
Long term action: If you use plastic cups, plates, cutlery etc. at a party, picnic or BBQ, wash them and reuse them - don't throw them away!
Long term action: Buy music online and use an MP3 player instead of buying CDs.
Could you make a Christmas or Birthday card or present instead of buying something?
'If you have large gardens could your family mow some parts a bit less, encourage tall grasses & more wildlife.
Use recycled or Forest Stewardship Council (FSC) certified paper
Send celebration e-cards or texts.
Avoid the use of patio heaters.
Do you really need another computer, laptop, blackberry, printer, scanner etc. in your household?
Do you really need to get a new computer?
Long term action: Organise a clothes swapping night
Make your own lunch instead of buying sandwiches
Long term action: When eating out, can you find a restaurant that uses local produce?
Long term action: If you are buying new furniture, ensure that any wood used comes from forests that have been sustainably managed. Look for the Forest Stewardship Council (FSC) logo on products.
'Long term action: When buying new equipment check lifespan, guarantee and if it can be easily repaired.
Long term action: When doing home DIY use timber that is reclaimed, or that is Forest Stewardship Council certified (FSC).
Can you use public transport to get to work? Find out about bus and train times.
Use public transport instead of driving to work - even if it's just for one day a week.
Walk or cycle to work instead of using your car
Long term action: Use lift sharing when travelling to work.
Turn off the engine when you are not driving (e.g., if you are waiting for someone or stuck in traffic)
Take part in or set up a walking bus group for your children's school.
For short journeys, try not to use the car. Walk or cycle instead.
Change to: Ensure tyres at correct pressure. Instead of: Check your tyre pressure
Plan your journeys to avoid congestion. Use Satnav or similar IT applications to avoid traffic congestion and reduce the amount of wasted journey time.
Long term action: If you don't have a bike, consider buying one under the cycle to work scheme. Or buy a second hand one.
Remove roof racks / boxes and cycle racks from your car. Clear out any heavy clutter you might have in your car.
Accelerate slowly and smoothly, maintain a steady speed (within the speed limit!) and anticipate your stops and starts.
Long term action: If you are buying a car, think about the energy and carbon used to produce it, as well as it's fuel efficiency when you are using it.
Find out what speed you should drive your car at for maximum efficiency.
Stick to the most efficient speed of your car to minimise fuel consumption.
If you live near a supermarket, can you walk or cycle there to do your shopping?
If you drive to the supermarket consider doing your weekly supermarket shop online
Investigate Eco driving techniques.
Reduce your car trips to the supermarket - do one big weekly shop, or combine your shopping trip with another car journey.
Could your employer provide a shuttle bus service for employees?
Lobby your employer to provide a bike pool for short work journeys
Talk to your employer about organising lower carbon travel to work options
Long term action: Reduce the amount of meetings you travel to by using tele and video conferencing.
'Contact your local MSPs and councillors and campaign for improved transport and cycling infrastructure
Long term action: Provide advanced driver training and/ or Eco driving training to all those who drive company vehicles.
Ensure vehicles are correctly maintained.
Long term action: Reduce the amount of business flights you take, try to travel by public transport or lift share to get to a meeting.
Long term action: Try to reduce the number of flights you take a year
Long term action: Plan a UK based holiday rather than flying abroad
Long term action: As well as deciding to holiday in the UK, choose destinations reached by coach or train
Long term action: If you are travelling to Europe for holiday or work, consider using public transport or driving
Long term action: Convert to lpg fuel
Get your food shopping delivery at the same time as your neighbours.
Buy blocks of soap instead of bottles of soap
If you have a dual flushing toilet, make sure you use the right flush!
Wear slippers instead of outdoor shoes in the house.
Try to wear clothes for longer and reduce the amount of washes you do.
Use a lower temperature wash on your washing machine.
Try to reduce the number of times you use the washing machine each week.
If you live in shared accommodation, consider filling the washing machine up with several peoples clothes rather than doing half loads.
Don't leave the taps or shower running when you are not using it.
Where appropriate, re-use any cups, glasses or dishes rather than taking a clean one every time.
Reduce water use when washing pots by washing the cleaner things first (glasses, cups), then moving on to the greasy things.
Have a the shower instead of a bath
Reduce the time you spend in the shower.
Use reusable dishcloths instead of disposable ones.
Switch to environmentally friendly cleaning products
Fix leaky taps
If you have a child in nappies, consider using reusable or semi-biodegradable nappies instead of disposable ones.
Pre soak heavily soiled clothes to decrease necessity to wash at high temperatures
Use recycled or Forest Stewardship Council Certified (FSC) toilet paper
Wait for a full load before washing clothes.
Try to exchange bottled water for tap water
At work, do you need cleaners every day? Redeploy them to other areas of work, such as recycling
Set up a water butt and use the water in it to water the garden and houseplants.
Share a bath
Dry your clothes outside instead of using a tumble dryer
Long term action: If you use a tumble drier, use dryer balls
Long term action: Purchase the most energy efficient shower you could.
Long term action: Install a water meter
Ask your family if they are recycling and if not ask them what is stopping them.
Find out what you can recycle at home
Recycle your waste
Put up the waste collection calendar, available from Stirling Council
Recycle drinks cans
Reuse or recycle your ink cartridges
Plan your meals in advance to help you avoid food waste
Recycle all glass bottles
Be aware of food packaging when buying food this week
When conventional batteries wear out, replace them with rechargeable ones
Use reusable items instead of disposable ones
Use waste packaging for kids craft activities
Donate unwanted items to charity shops or community projects instead of binning them
Label your waste and recycling bins so everyone knows what should go in them
Re-use shredded paper, e.g. when packing products. Or compost it.
Buy envelopes from recycled materials whenever possible
Do you have staff / company executive names on your headed paper? Change to a system where the relevant names are put in automatically by individual computers
Change computer / printer / photocopier settings so that double sided printing happens automatically.
Change computer / printer / photocopier settings so that double sided printing happens automatically.
Fax machine cover sheets - Print or photocopy fax machine cover sheets onto the back of one sided used paper until no one sided paper remaining.
Print or photocopy internal forms and notices onto the back of one sided used paper, until no one sided paper left.
Buy refilled printer cartridges
Remove disposable cups from your drinking water dispenser. Use glasses instead.
Replace bottled drinking water dispensers with a water cooler / filter
When you buy new desks etc. for the office, consider getting good quality second hand ones
If you still use disposable cups and plates in your workplace, replace these with biodegradable alternatives, or join a local plastic cup recycling scheme
Buy recycled paper stationery and filing products. Most large stationery companies now stock these products
Buy recycled paper stationery and filing products. Most large stationery companies now stock these products
Long term action: Recycle your old bike
Make notebooks from scrap paper
Make sure your old mobile phones and other gadgets don’t end up in the bin. Take them to a charity shop or recycle them.
'Ensure that recycling bins have been put out on correct days
Buy items with less packaging
Write to organisations to stop them sending junk mail to you.
Register with the Mailing Preference Service to reduce junk mail
Register to opt out of the post office's Door to Door service
Use online services
Opt out of the edited version of the electoral register
Go through the mail being sent to you/your business and think about whether you need to receive it
Consider starting a home, school or work composting scheme
Long term action: Try to get clothes repaired instead of buying new ones
Long term action: Swap or recycle children’s toys

Increase the amount of waste that gets recycled in your business by ensuring that employees are trained, valued, recognised and rewarded. Start changing the perception of this activity as being crucial and integral to the business.
